entry.title: Falling in and out of love with Moltbot
entry.content:
Maybe someday you’ll have a genie in your laptop working for you 24/7. Today is not that day
 ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏  ͏ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­  
 
Platformer
Falling in and out of love with Moltbot

Maybe someday you’ll have a genie in your laptop working for you 24/7. Today is not that day
By Casey Newton • 29 Jan 2026 View in browser
View in browser
(Molt.bot)
 
 

This is a column about AI. My boyfriend works at Anthropic. See my full ethics disclosure here.

I.

One of my chief biases as a tech journalist is that I like trying new software. Show me a promising new tool and I will, at the drop of a hat, give my entire inbox and calendar over to it. Over time I have begun to rein in this tendency, recognizing that I typically lose more time to so-called productivity tools than I gain from them. And yet still, whenever I read about some groundbreaking widget, I find myself reaching to download it. 

And so last week, when I read a piece titled “Clawdbot Showed Me What the Future of Personal AI Assistants Looks Like,” I knew I was in trouble. The article, written by the great Federico Viticci at MacStories, described an open-source, locally running artificial intelligence that connected to all the most important services in his life. He spoke to it via voice notes and Telegram, and used it to replace (for free) automations that he previously paid for on Zapier. If he could imagine it, Viticci wrote, there was a good chance the tool — then called Clawdbot — could build it. It made him wonder what future apps would even have once AI became sufficiently powerful. 

Viticci wrote:

Clawdbot is a boutique, nerdy project right now, but consider it as an underlying trend going forward: when the major consumer LLMs become smart and intuitive enough to adapt to you on-demand for any given functionality – when you’ll eventually be able to ask Claude or ChatGPT to do or create anything on your computer with no Terminal UI – what will become of “apps” created by professional developers? I especially worry about standalone utility apps: if Clawdbot can create a virtual remote for my LG television (something I did) or give me a personalized report with voice every morning (another cron job I set up) that work exactly the way I want, why should I even bother going to the App Store to look for pre-built solutions made by someone else? What happens to Shortcuts when any “automation” I may want to carefully create is actually just a text message to a digital assistant away? 

These are excellent questions. The more I have been using Claude Code, the more I have found myself wondering the same things. For the moment, Claude Code has several limitations that prevent it from taking over the computer in the way that Viticci describes. And yet, reading about Clawdbot, I became curious whether that future might be closer than I imagined.

And so last Saturday, I visited the website for Clawdbot.

In many ways, Clawdbot resembled Claude Code. The resemblance was close enough that Anthropic asked its solo developer, Peter Steinberger, to change the name. Thus Clawdbot is now Moltbot; I’ll refer to it as such throughout the rest of this article.

Like Claude Code, Moltbot is installed via a terminal command and can then interact with the large language model of your choice. (You have to bring your own API key; I plugged in keys from Anthropic, OpenAI and Google to enable various different features.) Also like Claude, Moltbot can generate text and write code.  

But Moltbot differs from a normal LLM in a handful of ways I found appealing. 

One, it runs locally on your machine. (In my case, a 2024 M4 MacBook Pro.) Messages get sent to the AI providers, of course. But the core infrastructure, which handles Moltbot’s memory, scripts and other tools, stays on your computer.

Two, you can add it to the messaging app of your choice: Telegram, Discord, Slack and Signal among them. This is nice for several reasons, one of them being that it makes it easy to message Moltbot from your phone.

And three, Moltbot promised to have a persistent memory. Claude Code forgets much of what happens in any given session, and must constantly be reminded. Moltbot creates a series of daily notes about your interactions that it can load into the LLM’s context window, allegedly giving it improved recall compared to a standard command-line tool.

Over on YouTube, recommendations led me to several hypebeasts who promised me that Moltbot would do much more. Creators on X and YouTube said they had bought Mac minis to allow the tool then known as Clawdbot to run continuously. “Clawdbot is the most powerful AI tool I’ve ever used in my life,” read the title of a representative video from Alex Finn, who assured me that Moltbot would serve as my “24/7 AI employee.” Another creator promised to tell me “How I use Clawdbot to Run My Business and Life 24/7.” 

By the end of the weekend, Best Buy had sold out of Mac minis in San Francisco. 

I was convinced. I installed Moltbot with that single command, and onboarding proved refreshingly simple. (It was, in hindsight, the high-water mark of my time with the tool.)

Within 10 minutes or so, I had wired up Moltbot to many of the core systems I use in my life: an email account, my calendar, Notion, Todoist, and Capacities, among others. Once that was working, I set about working on the project that would come to define the week I spent with Moltbot: a highly personalized morning briefing that would bring together all the strands of my life into a single place. 

II.   

I realize this project sounds kind of boring. 

But one, it offered me a chance to see what Moltbot could do with all of those services I had stitched together. Two, if it worked, I would create something unique to me that I wouldn’t have been able to build myself.

And finally — which I realized only at the end of the process — the specific ways in which it broke persuaded me to uninstall Moltbot from my computer.

 

Upgrade to continue reading.

Become a paid member of Platformer to get access to all premium content.

entry.title: The Newest Olympic Sport, Melania's Director, and Undeserving Grammy Winners
entry.content:
Plus: What to eat when nothing sounds good
 
By the Numbers
Threats Against Members of Congress Skyrocketed in 2025
The new stat was released following startling incidents involving Ilhan Omar and Maxwell Frost.

Share
 
 
Entertainment
Why disgraced Rush Hour director Brett Ratner was the only man for the Melania documentary
The director, who has been accused of sexual misconduct by multiple women, lost a lucrative production deal during the #MeToo era. Now, as Kevin E G Perry reports, he is plotting a Hollywood comeback with an expensive documentary about the First Lady and Trump-backed plans to revive his most famous franchise.
The Independent
Kevin E G Perry
Share

What to eat when nothing sounds good
A look at how stress, fatigue and emotion shape appetite and how to respond with care.

The only person to win an Olympic medal and a Nobel Peace Prize
Philip Noel-Baker ran middle-distance races at the Olympics before dedicating his life to disarmament.

We tally the 10 most underserving Album of the Year winners in Grammy Awards history: records that beat The Beatles, Radiohead, and Beyonc.

Jonah Krueger
Share
 
 
Photojournalism

entry.title: Welcome to Six Steps to Calm
entry.content:
Thank you for signing up to our BBC newsletter course
View this email online
Melissa Hogenboom
Dear Rod,

I'm Melissa Hogenboom, a science writer and editor at the BBC, and I'm excited to welcome you to Six Steps to Calm.

By the end of this six-part BBC newsletter course, you'll have been introduced to a variety of simple, science-backed exercises which are all designed to help you soothe stress from the comfort of your own home. You should finish the course feeling calmer and with a strong selection of anti-anxiety tools in your armoury, should you need them in the future.

You'll receive an email from me every Sunday for the next six weeks. To ensure you don't miss an edition, please add Six Steps to Calm to your list of safe senders and, if you use Gmail, move this email into your Primary tab. This shows your email provider that you want to receive these newsletters.

In between emails, you can explore the BBC's latest health and wellness stories from around the world here. You can also subscribe to Health Fix, our weekly newsletter which provides trusted insights for better health and wellbeing, here.

I'd love to know what you think of Six Steps to Calm. You can let me know your feedback and how you get on with the various exercises at any time by emailing me here.

Best wishes,

Melissa Hogenboom
Science writer

PS: Six Steps to Calm is just one of the many free emails offered by the BBC, with topics including US politics, climate change and history. Click here to browse our offering and sign up for more newsletters.
Follow us here

entry.title: Welcome to Health Fix
entry.content:
Thank you for signing up to our weekly BBC newsletter
View this email online
Melissa Hogenboom
Dear Rod,

I'm Melissa Hogenboom, a science writer, author and BBC editor, and I'm excited to welcome you to Health Fix – the BBC's dedicated health newsletter.

Every Wednesday, I'll bring you trusted, science-backed insights on how you can improve your health and wellbeing, from body to mind. Each edition will touch on universal concerns and questions, from getting better sleep to improving your skin's health, and there'll also be an opportunity for you to ask your own health-related questions.

You are joining a band of readers whose loyalty to the newsletter helped it win Best Health and Lifestyle Newsletter 2025 at The Publisher Newsletter Awards in June – just six months after launching. We are grateful for all the support.

To ensure you don't miss an edition, please add Health Fix to your list of safe senders and, if you use Gmail, move this email into your Primary tab. This shows your email provider that you want to receive these newsletters.

In-between emails, you can explore the BBC's latest health and wellness stories from around the world here. You might also be interested in signing up for Six Steps to Calm, our six-part email course that’s designed to help you deal with stress and anxiety.

I'd love to know what you think of Health Fix. You can let me know your feedback – or submit a health-related question to be answered in our "ask an expert" section – at any time here.

Best wishes,

Melissa Hogenboom
@melissa_hogenboom
Science writer, author and BBC editor

PS: Health Fix is just one of the many free emails and newsletter courses offered by the BBC, with topics including US politics, climate change, the British Royal Family and global history. Click here to browse our offering and sign up for more newsletters.
Follow us here

entry.title: Welcome to The Essential List
entry.content:
Your twice-weekly newsletter for the best BBC features and more
View this email online
Dear Rod,

Thank you for signing up to The Essential List, a twice-weekly newsletter that brings the best of the BBC to your inbox every Tuesday and Friday.

In each edition, our world-class editors handpick a selection of the BBC's smartest, sharpest and most entertaining articles, videos and podcast episodes. Consider it the most essential of our offering. 

The Essential List is just one of a growing slate of newsletters from the BBC on topics ranging from the Royal Family to US politics. Explore all those available to you here.

We hope you enjoy reading The Essential List. Please share it with a friend if you think they'd like the newsletter and, if you have any feedback or queries, you can drop us a line.

Thanks for being a reader,

Laura Norkin
Executive Managing Editor, Global Features
Follow us here
You've received this email because you've signed up to the BBC The Essential List newsletter.

entry.title: Welcome to Platformer
entry.content:
Hey, thanks for subscribing toPlatformer!

Free subscribers receive one full edition each week. Paid subscribers receive three, arriving Monday, Tuesday, and Thursday. All updates will arrive straight to your inbox around 5PM PT. If youre curious about what to expect,this guide outlines my journalistic interests, how I see the world, and all the ways you can get in touch with me. I also invite you to read myethics policy.

My hope is that you find that this newsletter saves you time and makes you smarter. If you find that it's not doing either for you, it won't hurt my feelings if you unsubscribe.

I'm always eager to hear your feedback please email me at casey@platformer.news, or simply reply to any issue.

Just as an FYI, monthly subscriptions auto-renew, so we'll bill your card/payment method monthly. If you are on an annual subscription, that will auto-renew in a year, and we'll let you know ahead of time. If you need to stop your current subscription for any reason, you can do that by going to https://www.platformer.news#/portal/accountor simply logging into the site with your email and clicking the account links in the top bar or in the small account bubble in the bottom right corner.

Yours,

Casey
Sent on behalf of Platformer by Outpost Publishers Cooperative
1267 Willis St., Suite 200, Redding, CA 96001
Don't like these emails? Unsubscribe.
Powered by Outpost.
